texts.definition: Games where variations in players' physical locations are part of the gameplay but where the current locations are reported to the game by the players.
markups: <style="Definition">Games where variations in players' physical locations are part of the gameplay but where the current locations are reported to the game by the players.</style>

Some games use the location of players as input of the game state but need this information to be reported to where the game state is stored. Games have <style="CurrentLink">Self-Reported Positioning</style> when this is done by the explicit actions of players

Note: this pattern complies with the original definition of the concept of Self-Reported Positioning in that players choose what location to report and can thereby report locations far from where they actually are.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Uncle%20Roy%20All%20Around%20You">Uncle Roy All Around You</link></style> is the game that originated the concept of <style="CurrentLink">Self-Reported Positioning</style>.

Location-based social network such as Foursquare and Gowalla let players check-in whenever they wish but the systems provide the actual information, so players cannot report other locations that ones where they actually are.

<style="CurrentLink">Self-Reported Positioning</style> requires that a game makes use of <style="Link"><link="player-location-proximity">Player-Location Proximity</link></style>, but it is the easiest way to support this pattern since one only needs to make use of a communication system, not a sensing technology and a communication system.

<style="CurrentLink">Self-Reported Positioning</style> is an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Interface%20Patterns">Interface pattern</link></style> since it makes players use an interface to tell the game system their  positions.

<style="CurrentLink">Self-Reported Positioning</style> provides a narrow form of <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>. It however does so within a context where players report to some game system so it can also be seen as a way of modulating <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style>. Since it loosens the requirements of where players actually are, it makes games with <style="Link"><link="player-location-proximity">Player-Location Proximity</link></style> have <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>. This also helps provide <style="Link"><link="social-adaptability">Social Adaptability</link></style> since players do not need to go places if they do not have the time or want, or do not want to disturb those in the locations.
